intro: Mesanthophora, commonly known as the false dandelion, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Asteraceae. It consists of several species, most of which are native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. The plants typically have basal leaves that are lanceolate or ovate in shape, with a hairy texture. They produce small, yellow flowers arranged in a composite head, which are followed by fluffy, white seeds for wind dispersal. Mesanthophora species are often found in meadows, roadsides, and disturbed soils, thriving in sunny to partially shaded environments.
